subject: Re: [junit] help with test methods
msgSnippet: ... Typically, no. Tests do not invoke other tests. Instead, simply refactor. Start here, with duplication in the tests: public void testAddBookOk() {
messageBody:
guilherme mello wrote:
> Hi...
>
> I have this method to add a book in library:
>
> public void testAddBookOk() {
> book.setTitleBook("The lord of rings");
> library.addBook(book);
> }
>
> And i have this method to listAllBooks:
>
> public void testListAllBooks() {
> testAddBookOk();
> books = library.listAllBooks();
>
> assertEquals(books.get(0), "The lord of rings");
> }
>
> is correct I to call the method testAddBookOk() in the body of
> testListAllBooks ?

Typically, no. Tests do not invoke other tests. Instead, simply refactor.

Start here, with duplication in the tests:

public void testAddBookOk() {
book.setTitleBook("The lord of rings");
library.addBook(book);
}

public void testListAllBooks() {
book.setTitleBook("The lord of rings");
library.addBook(book);
books = library.listAllBooks();
assertEquals(books.get(0), "The lord of rings");
}

Now we have duplication at the beginning of these tests. Extract this
code to setUp():

protected void setUp() {
book.setTitleBook("The lord of rings");
library.addBook(book);
}

public void testAddBookOk() {
// what do we assert here?
}

public void testListAllBooks() {
books = library.listAllBooks();
assertEquals(books.get(0), "The lord of rings");
}

When I do this, I notice that one tests no longer has any code in it.
There is usually an assertion in every test. What can we assert here?
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
